PROPOSITION.TITRE: Two choral repertoires are performed at the highest-ranking rituals.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The badong and simbong choruses are performed at two different rituals, at the highest point of the sacrificial ladder. They are not only sung but also danced, on the eve of the days of sacrifice, in the courtyard area.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Rehearsal of simbong at Baruppu', 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The two choruses badong and simbong are organized extremely hierarchically.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In badong and simbong choruses, there is a rule of subordination between a leader, his assistants, and the body of the chorus. This subordination emphasizes the leader’s superiority as he alone has the skills of ornamentation. The singers’interdependence is noticeable in the division of musical tasks: they never express themselves as individuals but always as parts of a whole.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Badong around the body, 1991.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Both choruses use experienced groups of singers, remunerated, and representing local communities.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Mengkendek, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The relation between the song and the words is identical for each chorus.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Each song (badong or simbong) is based on a narrative matrix performed at the start of the ritual by the officiants and then taken up by the chorus: in the West, the ossoran badong (hagiography of the deceased), in the East, the samparan simbong (panegyric of a living person). The words of these songs are different, but certain parts are common. They have similar functions: the badong is praise for the deceased and the simbong is praise for the owner of the house who has organized the celebration.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Officiant Ne' Salombe’during a simbong peformance, Baruppu', 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Badong and simbong share similar acoustics.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The choruses of the West and East have the same density of powerful spectral masses, which invade the complete space. Vocalic play between the vowels [o] and [e] are performed in both repertoires. They represent a ‘turning around’, an ‘inversion’.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The same type of vocal technique is used in both choruses.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Whether in badong or simbong, the soloist’s vocal technique is similar: the soloist has to embroider in seconds. This skill is called ma'tindok, ma'korrok, or mangindo’i.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The ornamentalist in a badong.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: A mode of polymusical performing is common to both choral forms.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the two highest rituals, groups sing side-by-side but separately, at some points in the rite. Although these types of music are not subject to any rhythmical coordination, they are still performed simultaneously: they are juxtaposed. This juxtaposition is fixed, sustained and deliberate.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Polybadong during a funeral ritual, Tapparan, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Badong and simbong have different choreographies.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The badong is performed in a circle; the simbong in an arc.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong at the departure for the grave, 1993.
Simbong chorus at Tiroan (Bittuang), Dec. 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Badong and simbong differ in their choral arrangements.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The badong chorus is subdivided into four solo groups singing antiphonally, whereas the simbong has multiple choruses that are not internally subdivided but sing antiphonally each to each.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong organisation.
Simbong disposition.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalences between badong and simbong choruses.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The equivalences between these choruses are both extra-musical and musical in nature.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Polymusic during a funeral celebration, 1993.
Polymusic during a celebration of the East, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Contrasts between the badong and simbong choruses.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Badong and simbong are not strictly equivalent, as they are identical acoustically but different in musical form: in timed treatment of words and accentual dynamics. Similarities and differences are synthesized in the table below.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Table of differences between badong and simbong.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: A different musical relationship to the ritual.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Whereas the badong has the role of marking the moving of the deceased’s body, the simbong does not accompany any action.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The badong marks the body’s being moved, 1993.
The simbong does not mark any specific ritual action, Tiroan (Bittuang), 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: A different treatment of the words.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the badong song, the words are shattered through unlimited melismas whilst those of the simbong remain comprehensible. Unlike the badong, where the consonants are weakened (to the point of nearly disappearing), in the simbong, consonants are prominent and become a powerful force shaping the timbre. The consonant enables the singer to play with his voice. The badong accentuates the rhythmic vigor but weakens the word, while the simbong weakens the rhythmic dynamism but accentuates the word. This inversion makes sense: the two repertoires are both opposite and complementary.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong of Baruppu', Rindingallo, recorded at Tikala, 1993.
Simbong of Poka, Rindingallo, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Whereas the badong, metered, evokes discontinuous time, the simbong uses mainly an unmetered and continuous time. Continuity, in fact, invades even the measured parts of simbong, the lines being interrupted by long unmetered sustained tones. The simbong’s static continuity, linked to the continuous temporal flow, is thus in opposition to the dynamic discontinuity of the badong.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong from Rantetayo, lines 8-9, Tapparan, July 1993.
Simbong from Awan, lines 14-17, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Whereas the badong is in unison with heterophony, simbong consists of a drone one moving line.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Beginning of a badong at Limbong (Pangngala'), 1993.
Notation of simbong (‘Marassamo...’), Deri, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: In the dancing choruses, the bali link designates a coupled relationship.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Badong and simbong are coupled: they are similar in some ways and largely opposed in others.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Two cocks in inverse positions on the gable of a house.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The solo declamations are pronounced at great celebrations.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The declamations take place if at least one buffalo has been sacrificed, as part of the celebrations for high-ranking persons or families.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Under the platform (bala’kaan), Bokko, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The declamations are solos integrated into the choruses.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The solo declamations are performed within the badong or simbong/nani choruses.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Solo declamation at the bua’ kasalle ritual, Tiroan, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Same acoustic specificities in declamations in the East and in the West.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Apocope, recto tono and harmonic impoverishment are three features distinguishing this type of declamation, called retteng (or singgi’ in certain regions).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Spectrogram of a retteng for the deceased, showing the technique of harmonic impoverishment at end of breath.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Apocope and vocalic emaciation in the East.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The solo declamations are made by several soloists in turn.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The alternation of the soloists can be conflictual, especially at the funerals.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Badong singers, Penduan Ra'ba', 2001.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Back-and-forth stanzas in the retteng deata.
Back-and-forth stanzas in the funeral retteng.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The declamations develop a similar literary content.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The solo declamations borrow certain lines from the textual matrix of the choruses (ossoran badong, samparan simbong) –often either a personal homage or a satire of the deceased or sponsor of the bua’ kasalle. The socio-political issues involved render this declaration particularly dangerous.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Example of a retteng in the form of homage to the deceased.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The solo declamations in the East and the West are formally equivalent.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Though they differ in certain respects with regard to melody, rhythm, lyrics, and intonation, the retteng to mate and retteng deata solo declamations have the same musical form.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Retteng solo at the ma’kurre sumanga’ thanksgiving celebration, Tiroan (Bittuang), 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The bali linking the solo declamations designates a paired relationship.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Apart from certain melodico-rhythmic and literary differences, the solo declamations constitute a single musical form. The concept bali in this case joins two repertoires, similar in form for their sound composition (solo), musical organisation (declamation recto tono), delivery (standing stock still), and context (celebrations of equal rank). These repertoires differ in the words sung and the melodic varieties peculiar to each region.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Identical wood panels on a Toraja house.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The dondi’ and serang mundan choruses are mixed-sex and open to all.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Mixed and open to all, these choruses can be performed throughout the celebration by non-specialists, in any numbers. Women and men of all ages sing together.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The mixed choruses treat the words in the same way.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Every line (whether octosyllabicor heptasyllabic) is pronounced following a melodic matrix, either syllabically or melismatically. The singers mark a pause between each line.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: A single melodico-rhythmic structure unites the dondi’ and serang mundan.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The phrases are produced following a chant structure: ascent to a recitation tone, recitation on one tone, and then descent to a terminal tone.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The mixed choruses are not danced.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Dondi’ and serang mundan are sung sitting. Occasionally, the serang mundan is sung standing. In the same way, the badong can take the form of the dondi’ and vice-versa.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Dondi’ singers at dawn, Pangala', 1991.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The words sung, in both cases, have an aphoristic form.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Whereas the dondi’ links quatrains about existence, separation, death, and love, the serang mundan strings together enigmatic quatrains about life only.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Extracts from dondi’ and serang mundan.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies of the non-dancing mixed choruses.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The formal equivalences are almost total.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Dondi’ and serang mundan.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The bali link joining the mixed choruses designates a paired relationship.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Bali joins two repertoires that are similar in form in the sound composition (mixed chorus, musical organisation; delivery mode) and in the context (rituals of equivalent rank). These repertoires differ only in their words and melodic variations.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Identical wooden panels engraved on a Toraja house.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The pakorong ritual ’s musical pieces must answer each other in pairs.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Flautists, pakorong ritual, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The preambles to the great songs are narratives.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Before the choruses perform, preambles (ossoran, samparan) are pronounced. These are long poems, of 500 to 1,000 lines, in a narrative logic, constructed according to a chronological order.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The officiant Ne’Lumbaa addresses the deceased through ma’kakarun, 2000.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The preambles to badong and simbong are eulogies.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The eulogy of the nobles is central. Through describing their goods, success, wealth and abundance, the beings sung –living or dead –are glorified and elevated by recalling the exemplary nature of their life. This reminder consolidates and reaffirms the individuals’status.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: From samparan simbong, lines 484 and ff., 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The preambles to badong and simbong use the same stanza-form.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the narratives of badong and simbong, the octosyllabic lines are regrouped in couplets, tercets, or quatrains.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Examples of stanzas from ossoran badong and samparan simbong narrative.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The preambles to the songs are performed in a chanted manner.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The narratives preceding the dances (badong and simbong) are introduced by an officiant who performs a long speech in verses. Parts of this chanted speech are then sung by the choruses.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Chanted declamation, Tiroan, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The preambles to badong and simbong consist of passages selected from the complete, much longer hagiography.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The narratives, the most valued forms, constitute a stock of verses from which short forms can be generated. Other lyrics, not from the hagiography, may also be inserted.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: In bold: the verse of the narrative repeated by the singers. From ossoran badong collected in 1993. Sound example recorded at Tapparan, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Simbong and badong, when sung, are founded on the same prosody.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In these two repertoires, the song is composed of a succession of stanzas terminated by a clausula (tampak).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: From stanzas of simbong and badong.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies of the narrative poems.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The two poems, ossoran badong and samparan simbong, are equivalent in a number of ways. Each is declaimed by a solo officiant. In addition, they are the introductions to the collective songs badong and simbong.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The features common to the two narratives.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Differences between two narrative poems.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: There are differences in content between the two poems. Though both originate in praise, what is recounted is not identical. In the ossoran badong, the deceased ascends and moves on. In the ossoran badong, the centrifugal movement of the narrative is followed by a centripetal one, which is not the case in the samparan simbong.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Effigy of male deceased, Pangleon, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The bali linking the two great narratives designates a couple relationship.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The formal equivalences are more numerous than the differences.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Buffalo motif (pa'tedong) on a Toraja house.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The short poems are arranged aphoristically.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The short poems or ‘lyrical’poems sung while sitting (as dondi’, sengo, serang mundan, gelong maro, and gelong bugi') and performed in various celebrations have a common fragmentary and aphoristic element.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: From dondi’ and serang mundan, collected in 1991 and 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The short poems have a specific prosody.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The heptasyllable differentiates the lines of the dondi’ and serang mundan from the lines of the badong and simbong. In dondi’and serang mundan, the couplets are often formed of an octosyllable and a heptasyllable followed sometimes by a clausula of four or five syllables.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From dondi’, 1991.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The short poems have less value in the hierarchy than do the narratives.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The short poems are optional in the ritual, open to all to perform, pronounced without any fixed framework. They are most often sung sitting, but sometimes may also be sung standing.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Singers of dondi’, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The bali linking the short poems designates a paired relationship.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The equivalences between dondi’ and serang mundan reveal their paired relationship.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Identical motifs engraved on a house.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalences between ritual places and times.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The highest rituals take place in a dried paddy field outside the villages, either to the southwest or the northeast, on the side of the rising sun (rites of life) or the setting sun (rites of death). Both sides evince the same spatio-temporal organisation.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Preparation of the funeral area at Mengkendek, 1991.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: During the highest rituals, the courtyards are decorated with a red cloth in the West and a white one in the East.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Granary during funeral. The red cloth is called kaseda.
House during funeral.
Funeral at Sapan, 1993.
Blood red.
Rice-granary during the bua’ kasalle.
House during the bua’ kasalle, with its white banners.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Different sacrificial areas are used for the rites life and death. They are located outside the village –either to the southwest or the northeast of the house.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The funeral ceremonial field, rante pantunuan ‘field of slaughter’, Tapparan, 1993.
The megalith field, To' Barana', 1993.
Ceremonial field, bua’ kasalle, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: For the highest ritual of the East (bua’ kasalle), a high platform is erected (bala’kaan boro ‘splendid promontory’or gorang bulaan ‘golden tower’), from which the officiants perform the singgi’ eulogy. For the highest ritual of the West (rapasan), the ‘meat platform’(bala'kaan duku) is erected, from which the meat to be shared is thrown and the ancestors invoked.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: To' Barana', Ne’Sulo’s funerals, 2000.
The officiants on the platform (bala’kaan), To' Barana', 2000.
Bala’kaan at Pangleon, 1993.
Bala’kaan at Bokko, 1993.
Bala’kaan at Bokko, 1993.
Bala’kaan at Bokko, 1993.
Officiants going up to the platform, bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
The officiants praising the stem-family members (rapu), bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
Bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
Three officiants on the high platform, bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: The towers of residence –towers of seclusion.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: For the rituals of life and death, towers of residence are erected in the ceremonial area. The deceased rests throughout the celebration on the ‘engraved tower’ (lakkean sura’). The ‘officiated’woman (tumbang), fasting, will have to sleep on the tower of seclusion (gorang tumbang) for several days.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Lakkean sura’ tower, Penduan Ra'ba', 2001.
Lakkean sura’, where the deceased lies. Tallung Lipu, 1993.
Lakkean sura’, Sa'dan, 1993.
Gorang tumbang, at the bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
Gorang tumbang, at the bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
General view of the celebration site. Two towers are erected. In black, the platform of the tumbang, the ‘officiated’woman of the ritual. Bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies in symbols and artifacts.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the rituals of the East, the ceremonial mast (bate) is the equivalent of the mast of the West (bate lepong, bandera). The female effigy tumba' has as a counterpart the effigy of the deceased (tau-tau) in the funeral celebration. The tree (lumbaa langi') of the bua' kasalle has the tree (lumbaa padang) of the rapasan as a counterpart. The sandalwood (sendana bonga) of the East has as its counterpart, in the West, the white-hearted sandalwood (sendana dongka, Nooy-Palm 1979: 221). The megalithic stone simbuang batu has as its counterpart the forked tree parangka of the celebration bua’ (...) (Nooy-Palm 1986: 338).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Three ceremonial masts (bate) at the maro ritual, Torea, November 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The funeral ceremonial mast (bandera, bate lepong) has as its counterpart the mast of the East (bate) erected for the celebration maro or bate manurun.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Bandera mast, Ne' Sulo’s funeral, first celebration, To' Barana', 2000.
Bandera mast, Ne' Sulo’s funeral, first celebration, To' Barana', 2000.
Bate mast in the East, maro rite, 1993.
Bate mast maro rite, Torea, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: A stake is planted In the West and in the East, in the courtyard, upstream from the houses. Parts of the animal victims –horns, morsels of meat –and bamboo phials full of blood will be hung from it. The officiant sits beside it to pronounce his invocations. In the East the stake is called peturo langi' (Nooy-Palm 1986: 40). In the West, the stake is called simbuang kayu. The prospective victims of some sacrifices are attached to it.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Sacrificial stake, Ne’Sulo’s funeral, first part, at To' Barana', 2000.
The three bloods are spread on the stake: a dog’s, a cock’s, and a buffalo’s. It is the land of ‘three bloods’(padang ditallu rarai, singgi’, line 18).
Sacrificial stake, Indo’Serang’s funeral, Randanan, 1993. At the side, a child and ‘the death wrapper’(to mebalun).
Sacrificial stake at the ma’kurre sumanga’ thanksgiving celebration, Tiroan (Bittuang), 1993.
Animal offering stake, at the ma’kurre sumanga’ thanksgiving celebration, Tiroan (Bittuang), 1993.
Ritual stake (peturo langi' ‘show-heaven’), in front of the house, bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: An effigy is made for each ritual: in the West, a representation of the deceased; in the East, a female effigy (anak dara). In both cases, they can be returned to the vegetation at the end of the celebration.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Funeral effigy, Pangleon, 1993.
Anak dara effigy, photograph in R. Waterson 1991: 89. The effigy is formed by a type of trunk decorated with lianas and young plants.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the West, the belo tedong (‘buffalo jewel’), an ornament formed from pieces of value, is taken down to the field in the middle of the badong (Nooy-Palm 1986: 210). In the East, to manganda’ dancers wear a richly decorated headdress recalling buffalo horns. During the processions these ornaments are both taken down to the large field. They both have ceremonial fabrics, ornaments, and old coins.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Belo tedong ornament made for some funeral celebrations, Nooy-Palm 1986: 208.
Headdress made for the manganda’ dance, bua' kasalle ritual, 1993.
Headdress made for the manganda’ dance, bua' kasalle ritual, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The sandalwood (sendana bonga) of the East has as a counterpart, in the West, the white-hearted sandalwood. ‘During a rite of the ma'tomatua, the sendana dongka is planted, a variety of sandalwood tree differing from the heavenly sendana. This tree has no red heart-wood, like the sendana bonga; the heart-wood is whitish instead’(Nooy-Palm 1979: 221).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Sandalwood tree sendana bonga tree, planted in front of a house.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The counterpart of the megalithic stone (simbuang batu) would appear to be the forked tree parangka of the bua' kasalle ritual. ‘’The parangka erected for the bua' kasalle is a stone placed alongside the sandalwood tree, in front of the house where the ‘officiated’woman (tumbang) lives’’. (Nooy-Palm 1986: 322 and 338, note 6)

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: On a field of megaliths (simbuang batu), To' Barana', 2000.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Buffalo and bird heads are carved in wood (arae, katik) on the façades of some houses. The buffalo head is linked to the West and the head of the katik to the East. The buffalo’s head on the house indicates that the highest funeral has been performed, and the katik’s that the highest ritual of the East (bua' kasalle) has been performed (Waterson 1989: 61): these indicate that the houses have completed their ritual cycles. The bua' kasalle palanquins are decorated with long-necked-katik birds. Afterwards, these carvings will be attached to the house.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Toraja house façade.
In the photograph, the girl at the front holds on to the katik’s neck. Mamulle rite, during bua' kasalle, 1993.
The bird’s neck can be made out on the palanquin. Bua' kasalle at Deri, 1993.
The palanquin during the singgi’praising. Bua' kasalle, Deri 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies between officiants.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the highest funeral ritual, to mebalun (‘death wrapper’) is also called to burake bombo (‘priest of the deceased’s shade’) or to burake matampu' (‘priest of the setting sun’). His counterpart is the officiant to burake of the celebrations of the East (to burake tattiku’ in the north, or to burake tambolang in the south).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The burake playing on his small drum, bua' kasalle ritual, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: The officiants of the West and the East.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: In the West: the to mebalun with the covered-head widow, at Ne’Sulo’s funeral; behind in yellow, the deceased, 2000.
In the East: the burake making an offering, at the bua' kasalle ritual, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Guardian of the rites of the East.
Guardian of the rites of the West.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Dramaturgic equivalencies.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In both cases, in the West and in the East, the family members enter the sacrificial field in procession. They are led by a man wearing a horned head-dress. During the second stage of each of the rituals, the family members are lifted in palanquins and then shaken around a tower.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Funeral ceremony field, at Tapparan, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the two greatest celebrations –of both the West and the East –the entrance onto the ceremonial field is consecrated by the stem-family members, who enter in procession. In the rites of the West, the ma’pasonglo rite (‘descending in procession’to the field west of the house) opens the second funeral celebration. In the same way, in the rituals of the East, the second part of the bua’ kasalle opens with the family members entering the field east of the house in procession. In both cases, the celebration site is moved outside the house for the second stage.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The body is taken down to the sacrificial field in procession. The participants are joined together with a long red cloth. Ma’pasonglo rite, Tapparan, July 1993.
The body is taken down to the sacrificial field in procession.The participants are joined together with a long red cloth. Ma’pasonglo rite, Tapparan, July 1993.
Arrival of the funerary procession on the ceremonial field. Ma’pasonglo rite, Tapparan, July 1993.
1. Descent of the procession to the field. Bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
2. At the head of the procession, the officiants, then the ‘officiated’women and the helmeted dancers, Deri, 1993.
3. The members of the procession are joined together with a long blue cloth. Bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
4. The members of the procession arrive on the ceremonial field; they are joined together with a long blue cloth (sarita). Bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In both types of celebration, the participants are led onto the ceremonial field each time by one or more men wearing horned headdresses. According to H. Van der Veen, the to ussobo'i rante is a slave who enters the funeral field first to exorcise evil; in the same way, in the bua’ kasalle, the to menani (“the one who sings”) enters the ceremonial field (kala’paran) (cf. Veen’s unpublished notes in the Handschriften collection of the Royal Institute for Linguistics in Leiden; Hetty Nooy-Palm, personal communication, 1995).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Helmeted men at a funeral at Sa'dan matallo, 1993.
Ma'randing dancers, Ujung Pandang, Cultural Week, 1993.
An informant indicates that the man in the ‘horned’headdress guiding the stem-family members to the ceremonial field is called peta' badamo. Bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
Man in horned headdress introducing the procession onto the ceremonial field, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The same ritual occurs at the second stage in both types of celebration. This consists of raising and shaking stem-family members in palanquins and taking them round a tower. In the funerals, the corpse, the effigy and family members are carried and shaken in palanquins round the tower. In certain regions only, on the day of the buffalo sacrifices, the rite ma'parondo or ma'aparondo consists of carrying the deceased’s great-grandchildren on men’s backs –they are taken three times round the platform (lakkean) where the deceased is lying (Wilcox 1949: 85 and ff; Nooy-Palm 1986: 216-218).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Deceased carried on a palanquin, Sa'dan Matallo, 1993.
Deceased carried on a palanquin, Sa'dan Matallo, 1993.
The deceased carried on a palanquin, Randanan, Mengkendek, 1991.
The deceased is carried on a palanquin across paddy fields, Mengkendek, 1993.
At the bua’ kasalle, the ‘officiated’women, followed by other women, are also transported on palanquins. Deri, December 1993.
Mamulle rite, Deri 1993.
At the bua' kasalle, the ‘officiated’women, followed by other women, are also transported on palanquins. At Deri, December 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The participants turn around the platforms.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Funeral at Tapparan, July 1993.
Bua’ kasalle, Deri 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Choreographic equivalencies.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The randing funeral dance has as its counterpart the tenten, in the East. The equivalence between these dances can be seen not only in the costumes –the men wear a straw hat with false stylized horns and hold a buckler –but also in the gestures: they swing their right hands while holding their shields with the left; each dancer makes small jumps while advancing in file. In both cases, these warlike dancers preceded the participants’entrance onto the ceremonial field.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Dancers (to ma' randing). Makassar, *Pekan Budaya (‘cultural festival’), 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Equivalencies of the two dances, of the East and West
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The equivalence is confirmed thanks to Rolf de Maré’s film (1938) preserved at Stockholm. The tenten has disappeared today. Two hats from these dances are preserved, one in Stockholm at the Dance Museum and one in Jakarta at the National Museum (Museum Pusat). Only one of these hats is decorated with the shells. The headhunters’jackets –also present at the National Museum –were also decorated with shells (cf. sketch in Nooy-Palm 1986: 314). The hats are conical, half covered with skin, trimmed with hair (a trophy of headhunting?), decorated with white shells, and topped with five ornaments in metal leaf –the shortest, three in number, in the middle –the longer two being brass stylizations of buffalo horns

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Ma'randing, funeral at Sa'dan, 1993.
Ma'randing at a folklore festival, Makassar, 1993.
Man in horned helmet, day of the manganda’ rite, second part of the bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.
Helmeted men entering the arena, bua' kasalle, Deri.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies of acts of language.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Certain prayers of the rituals of the East are matched in the West.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Equivalencies of prayers, in the East and in the West.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies of the songs.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Figure of correspondences between the songs.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Equivalencies of the two great rituals
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Singgi' during bua' kasalle, Deri, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Differences between the two rituals.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Despite being linked by strong equivalences, the differences in these rituals are numerous: in the nature of the sacrifices (buffaloes on one side, pigs on the other), in the nature of the exchanges, even in the meaning of the rituals. The funeral is a starting point, the bua’ kasalle an arrival.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The arrival, bua’ kasalle, Deri, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The two highest rituals, in the West and in the East, form a couple.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: A certain number of elements common to both rituals match each other under different names: active ingredients –officiants, drum player, effigy etc.; stage (site, platform; setting),stake, tree, megalith; drama, entrance of the stem-family members, animal sacrifice. The sound worlds of both rituals also match. The sounds, like everything else, function in dyads (bali) and play a part in the ritual morphology.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The bali link in the two highest rituals, in the West and the East.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Equivalencies of the two great rituals.
Differences between the two great rituals.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: On the musical level, bali means ‘couple’.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Bali takes the meaning of couple when it joins repertoires both similar and opposite. The bali notion is defined both by a principle of identity (joining similar musical and choreographic structures), and of otherness (opposing different musical and choreographic structures).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong 1993.
Nani, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Link between the two danced choruses.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: On a ritual level, equivalencies join two seemingly separate rituals.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Progress of the deceased’s palanquin, Sa'dan, 1993.
Progress of the ‘officiated’women (mamulle), bua’ kasalle, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Link between the two highest rituals.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: On the musical level, bali means ‘pair’, linking together almost identical repertoires.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Bali takes the meaning of pair when it joins two repertoires, similar in their sound composition (male/solo/mixed chorus); musical organisation; delivery method (dancing/standing still/sitting); and context; and differing only in their words and melodic variations. Such is the case for retteng to mate/retteng deata and dondi’/serang mundan.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Dondi’ from Pangala', 1991.
Serang mundan at the bua’ kasalle, Deri, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Bali link for the declamations within the great choruses.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: On the musical level, bali signifies ‘returning’.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Graving on a house, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Bali signifies ‘returning melodies’.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the badong chorus, the musical phrases are passed back and forth among four groups as in a game of table tennis (badong sibali-bali ‘in response’). In the pakorong ritual, in the East, the groups pass pieces between each other so as to make pairs, failing which disorders could occur.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Sending back sound in the suling deata playing.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Bali signifies ‘to return verses’.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Bali also designates sending back structured words (sung or chanted poems). This principle is at work in several repertoires, in the spirit of informal jousts. In the dondi’, serang mundan, and simbong, the choruses answer one another (sibali) with stanzas close in semantic content, the aim especially being to prevent the return by stopping the opponent. Competition and rivalry are de rigueur.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Returning verse between simbong and dandan

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Exchanging dyads puts elements forming couples or pairs into play.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Mutual exchange is a concept that applies as much to musical repertoires as to rituals. Thus the rapasan elicits in response the bua’ kasalle, the two rituals forming a couple. Instead, the dondi’ and serang mundan form a pair. Sameness and difference are expressed and exchanged in a dynamic manner in large-scale rituals.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The ritual cycle is expressed by coupling pairs of various equivalencies.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: As a cosmic and mythical order, the ritual cycle is expressed by coupling pairs of equivalencies (bali). The two highest Toraja rituals form a couple (bali), which in turn generates a network of smaller pairs (bali), both ritual and musical. The whole ritual cycle aims at reunifying what has been taken apart: death in life, in an intermittent pendular movement, through a series of reciprocal joinings and responses.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The ritual path from death to life

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Returning dyads in couples and pairs.
